thread.title: Apartment owners fight to shut doors to short-stay operators, Airbnb
thread.title_full: Apartment owners fight to shut doors to short-stay operators, Airbnb

title: Apartment owners fight to shut doors to short-stay operators, Airbnb
text:
Apartment owners in the Watergate building have been battling to block short-stay accommodation.
Melbourne's apartment owners are forking out thousands of dollars in legal fees to fight short-stay operators as body corporates and building managers – worried about unruly behaviour, parties and property damage – try to evict them from their buildings.
Transient tenants leasing inner-city apartments through US-based websites like Airbnb and Couchsurfing are causing headaches for apartment dwellers, clogging lifts, making noise and damaging fittings.
A long-running dispute between apartment residents and short-stay operators in the Docklands Watergate building – estimated to have cost well over $100,000 in legal bills – will head back to the Supreme Court.
The issue has been tested at the Building Appeals Board, Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal.
Advertisement The fresh Supreme Court case follows a protracted battle between the Watergate owners' corporation and short-stay operator Paul Salter, who, along with his partner, Belinda Balcombe, runs Docklands Executive Apartments, which leases at least 11 units in the building to short-stay tenants.
In June, Mr Salter won a case in the VCAT brought against him by Watergate's managers. It was seeking to enforce a rule restraining owners from renting their units for less than 30 days at a time.
Late last year, Mr Salter won another separate, long-running and costly Supreme Court case against the City of Melbourne, which had argued short-term stays were breaching building regulations.
Watergate's managers would lodge a Supreme Court appeal against the VCAT decision after a special resolution passed by most of the building's 655 apartment owners was formalised last week, long-term resident and owners' corporation chairwoman Barbara Francis said.
"We've worked hard to create a wonderful building for owners to live in. If short stays escalate further, we could be overtaken not only by short-stay operators but Airbnb, which is already starting to happen," Ms Francis said.
"We live here. We are a Class 2 building that's not designed for short stays."
"It's the encroachment into our everyday life of people illegally tailgating into the car park, overloading lifts with luggage, commercial cleaners and laundry. We just want to have it stamped out," she said.
Mr Salter, who owns some of the Watergate apartments he lets, said the owners' corporation had failed to tell owners where the VCAT had erred or informed them about the cost of the Supreme Court appeal.
Mr Salter will fight the case with support from the short-term accommodation industry around Australia.
"This will be the final step in validating this part of the sharing economy," he said. "Provided it's run professionally, it [short stays] should have no impact whatsoever on the amenity of long-term owners."
